title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement eer@eremrah.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to airqualitytr
text: outlines propose change airqualitytr. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to airqualitytr
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to airqualitytr
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to airqualitytr
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("emraher/airqualitytr", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to airqualitytr
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to airqualitytr
text: Please note airqualitytr project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: airqualitytr provides easy access air quality monitoring data Turkish Ministry Environment, Urbanization Climate Change (See: https://sim.csb.gov.tr/). package enables researchers, analysts, policymakers download analyze environmental data across Turkey’s extensive network monitoring stations.

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Download hourly daily air quality measurements Access data 300+ monitoring stations across 81 provinces Retrieve multiple pollutants: PM10, PM2.5, SO2, CO, NO2, NOX, , O3 Download historical data automatic chunking Perform bulk downloads optional parallel processing

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Install development version GitHub: Load package:
code: # Install pak if not already installed if (!requireNamespace("pak", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("pak") }  # Install airqualitytr pak::pak("emraher/airqualitytr") library(airqualitytr) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(lubridate) library(purrr)

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Let’s download air quality data three simple steps:

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: First, explore available stations: station data includes: station_id: Unique identifier (UUID format) station_name: Human-readable station name city_id: City identifier city_name: City name Additional metadata: area type, company info, etc. Tip: Filter stations city name:
code: # Get all available stations stations <- list_stations()  # Glimpse stations glimpse(stations) # Find stations in Ankara ankara_stations <- stations |>   filter(grepl("Ankara", city_name, ignore.case = TRUE))  glimpse(ankara_stations)  # Find a specific station selected_station <- stations |>   filter(grepl("Sıhhıye", station_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) |>   slice(1)  glimpse(selected_station)  station_id <- selected_station$station_id

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: See pollutants available: Available parameters include: PM10: Particulate matter (≤10 μm) PM2.5: Fine particulate matter (≤2.5 μm) SO2: Sulfur dioxide CO: Carbon monoxide NO2: Nitrogen dioxide NOX: Nitrogen oxides : Nitric oxide O3: Ozone
code: # List available parameters (parameters <- list_parameters())

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Now download air quality measurements: resulting data frame contains: time: POSIXct timestamp (UTC timezone) station_id: Station identifier station_name: Station name city_name: City name parameter: Pollutant name value: Measurement value Additional metadata columns
code: # Download one month of hourly PM10 data data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # View the results glimpse(data)

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Download multiple pollutants simultaneously:
code: # Download PM10, NO2, and O3 multi_param_data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = c("PM10", "NO2", "O3"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-07 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Data is in long format - easy to analyze and plot ggplot(multi_param_data, aes(x = time, y = value, color = parameter)) +   geom_line() +   facet_wrap(~parameter, scales = "free_y", ncol = 1) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Air Quality Measurements",     subtitle = unique(multi_param_data$station_name),     x = "Time",     y = "Concentration",     color = "Pollutant"   )

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Choose appropriate frequency analysis:
code: # Hourly data - more detail, larger datasets hourly_data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-07 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Daily data - aggregated, smaller datasets # Note: Use longer date range for daily data as it aggregates measurements daily_data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "daily" )  # Compare sizes nrow(hourly_data) # ~168 rows (7 days * 24 hours) nrow(daily_data) # ~31 rows (31 days)

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: See provinces monitoring stations:
code: (cities <- list_cities())  # Count stations per city stations_per_city <- stations |>   count(city_name) |>   arrange(desc(n))  stations_per_city

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Find stations matching specific criteria:
code: # Stations in major cities major_cities <- c("İstanbul", "Ankara", "İzmir")  (major_city_stations <- stations |>   filter(city_name %in% major_cities))  # Stations with specific names (traffic_stations <- stations |>   filter(grepl("Trafik|Traffic", station_name, ignore.case = TRUE)))  # Get unique station types if available in metadata if ("area_type_name" %in% names(stations)) {   table(stations$area_type_name) }

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: columns use snake_case format consistency: station_id, station_name, city_name area_type, company_title, sector_code makes data manipulation easier predictable.

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: timestamps UTC:
code: # Check timezone attr(data$time, "tzone") # "UTC"  # Convert to Turkey time (UTC+3) if needed data_turkey_time <- data |>   mutate(time_local = with_tz(time, tzone = "Europe/Istanbul"))

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Missing measurements appear NA value column:
code: # Check for missing values summary(data$value)  # Count missing by parameter data |>   group_by(parameter) |>   summarize(     total = n(),     missing = sum(is.na(value)),     pct_missing = round(100 * missing / total, 1)   )  # Remove missing values for analysis clean_data <- data |>   filter(!is.na(value))

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: package validates inputs provides helpful error messages:
code: # Invalid station ID format try(   download_air_quality_data(     station_id = "invalid-id",     parameters = c("PM10"),     start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",     end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59"   ) ) # Error: Invalid station_id format. Must be a valid UUID.  # Invalid date range try(   download_air_quality_data(     station_id = station_id,     parameters = c("PM10"),     start_datetime = "2025-03-31 00:00",     end_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00" # End before start!   ) ) # Error: start_datetime must be before end_datetime  # Invalid parameter try(   download_air_quality_data(     station_id = station_id,     parameters = c("INVALID_PARAM"),     start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",     end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59"   ) ) # Error with suggestions for valid parameters

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
code: # Select 3 stations from different cities comparison_stations <- stations |>   filter(station_name %in% c("İstanbul - Beşiktaş", "Ankara - Çankaya", "İzmir - Karabağlar")) |>   group_by(city_name) |>   slice_sample(n = 1) |>   ungroup()  # Download data for each station comparison_data <- map_dfr(   comparison_stations$station_id,   ~ download_air_quality_data(     station_id = .x,     parameters = c("PM10"),     start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",     end_datetime = "2025-03-07 23:59",     frequency = "hourly"   ) )  # Compare stations ggplot(comparison_data, aes(x = time, y = value, color = station_name)) +   geom_line(alpha = 0.7) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "PM10 Comparison Across Stations",     x = "Time",     y = "PM10 (μg/m³)",     color = "Station"   )

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
code: # Download hourly data hourly <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Calculate daily statistics daily_stats <- hourly |>   filter(!is.na(value)) |>   mutate(date = as.Date(time)) |>   group_by(date, station_name, parameter) |>   summarize(     mean = mean(value),     min = min(value),     max = max(value),     sd = sd(value),     n = n(),     .groups = "drop"   )  daily_stats  # Plot with error bars ggplot(daily_stats, aes(x = date, y = mean)) +   geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = mean - sd, ymax = mean + sd), alpha = 0.2) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Daily PM10 Mean with Standard Deviation",     x = "Date",     y = "PM10 (μg/m³)"   )

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
code: # Download one month of hourly PM10 data data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "ed5b48d0-14c4-47a4-8ad1-b5db53ae72c9",   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Find hours exceeding WHO guidelines (PM10 > 45 μg/m³ daily mean) exceedances <- data |>   filter(!is.na(value)) |>   mutate(date = as.Date(time)) |>   group_by(date, station_name) |>   summarize(     daily_mean = mean(value),     daily_max = max(value),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   filter(daily_mean > 45)  exceedances  # Percentage of days exceeding guidelines pct_exceeding <- 100 * nrow(exceedances) / n_distinct(as.Date(data$time)) glue::glue("{scales::number(pct_exceeding, accuracy = 0.1)}% of days exceeded WHO PM10 guidelines\n")

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: Now ’ve learned basics, explore advanced topics: Parallel Processing - Speed bulk downloads Long-term Data Collection - Download years historical data Data Quality Assessment - Check clean data

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: encounter issues: Check Troubleshooting section README Review function documentation: ?download_air_quality_data Report bugs: https://github.com/emraher/airqualitytr/issues

title: Getting Started with airqualitytr
text: package accesses data Turkish Ministry Environment, Urbanization Climate Change. Please check official data policy Ministry’s website : - Data licensing terms - Citation requirements publications - Usage restrictions permissions Always cite data source package research.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Emrah Er. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Er, E. (2025). airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools. R package version 0.1.0. https://github.com/emraher/airqualitytr
code: @Manual{,   title = {airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools},   author = {Emrah Er},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/emraher/airqualitytr}, }

what: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: airqualitytr R package provides interface download explore air quality data Turkish Ministry Environment, Urbanization Climate Change. allows users : Download time series air quality data specified station parameters. Retrieve lists available cities. Retrieve station metadata. Retrieve available measurement parameters. functions enable researchers analysts quickly access analyze environmental data R workflow. Note: package initially created Emrah Er, subsequent improvements made using Claude Code.

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: can install development version GitHub using pak package:
code: pak::pak("emraher/airqualitytr")

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Load package explore available options:

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Retrieve tibble cities available filtering:
code: library(airqualitytr) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  (cities <- list_cities()) #> # A tibble: 81 × 2 #>    city_id                              city_name      #>    <chr>                                <chr>          #>  1 fddbbf7e-b853-431e-89d3-3522264e9383 Adana          #>  2 50cd2278-5573-4069-b7a9-2aacaf11431a Adıyaman       #>  3 c9b19ecd-1ffc-4616-ab1a-790aaf539bfe Afyonkarahisar #>  4 12b12d2f-1fd1-41a5-9142-7fe31e5134e3 Ağrı           #>  5 0d977726-b21e-4ef8-b852-e659286f1778 Aksaray        #>  6 b1bd61cf-1528-4a3e-9b45-c30cbf223035 Amasya         #>  7 8dbbe10c-b2c5-44c1-bb3e-90be45aee744 Ankara         #>  8 c414e607-cb0f-4226-997c-62a9eb563b2b Antalya        #>  9 d40a8bdb-1402-43e6-9e92-1f1c8484632c Ardahan        #> 10 a0da922a-ff51-4e7d-9f75-7fe44217d725 Artvin         #> # ℹ 71 more rows

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Get metadata available stations:
code: stations <- list_stations() head(stations) #> # A tibble: 6 × 20 #>   station_id    station_name city_id city_name town_id location station_sub_type #>   <chr>         <chr>        <chr>   <chr>     <chr>   <chr>               <int> #> 1 468478b7-ace… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (…                1 #> 2 9a381f61-657… Adana - Çuk… fddbbf… Adana     f2c0da… POINT (…               23 #> 3 bdc1f3d0-004… Adana - Doğ… fddbbf… Adana     fb3596… POINT (…                1 #> 4 c31a108f-90b… Adana - Met… fddbbf… Adana     fb3596… POINT (…                1 #> 5 c75060c5-d28… Adana - Val… fddbbf… Adana     f2c0da… POINT (…                1 #> 6 2b79754a-c5f… Adana-Seyhan fddbbf… Adana     f2c0da… POINT (…               23 #> # ℹ 13 more variables: company_id <chr>, company_id_name <chr>, #> #   station_group <int>, station_group_name <chr>, sector_code <int>, #> #   sector_code_name <chr>, basin_id <lgl>, data_periods <int>, #> #   source_type <int>, source_type_name <chr>, area_type <int>, #> #   area_type_name <chr>, is_portable <lgl>

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Retrieve tibble available measurement parameters (e.g., PM10, CO, NO2):
code: (params <- list_parameters()) #> # A tibble: 8 × 2 #>   id    name   #>   <chr> <chr>  #> 1 PM10  PM10   #> 2 PM25  PM 2.5 #> 3 SO2   SO2    #> 4 CO    CO     #> 5 NO2   NO2    #> 6 NOX   NOX    #> 7 NO    NO     #> 8 O3    O3

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Download time series air quality data specific station. must provide station’s unique identifier, select one measurement parameters, specify date range, choose data frequency (hourly daily). example: resulting tibble contains: time: POSIXct timestamp measurement. station_id: Station identifier API response. city_name: city name provided. station_name: station name provided. parameter: measurement parameter (e.g., “PM10”). value: corresponding measurement value.
code: # Example inputs: station_id <- "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080" parameters <- c("PM10", "CO", "NO2") start_datetime <- "2025-03-16 00:00" end_datetime <- "2025-04-15 00:00" frequency <- "hourly"  data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = parameters,   start_datetime = start_datetime,   end_datetime = end_datetime,   frequency = frequency ) head(data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 23 #>   time                station_id station_name city_id city_name town_id location #>   <dttm>              <chr>      <chr>        <chr>   <chr>     <chr>   <chr>    #> 1 2025-03-16 00:00:00 468478b7-… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (… #> 2 2025-03-16 00:00:00 468478b7-… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (… #> 3 2025-03-16 00:00:00 468478b7-… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (… #> 4 2025-03-16 01:00:00 468478b7-… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (… #> 5 2025-03-16 01:00:00 468478b7-… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (… #> 6 2025-03-16 01:00:00 468478b7-… Adana - Çat… fddbbf… Adana     f23102… POINT (… #> # ℹ 16 more variables: station_sub_type <int>, company_id <chr>, #> #   company_id_name <chr>, station_group <int>, station_group_name <chr>, #> #   sector_code <int>, sector_code_name <chr>, basin_id <lgl>, #> #   data_periods <int>, source_type <int>, source_type_name <chr>, #> #   area_type <int>, area_type_name <chr>, is_portable <lgl>, parameter <chr>, #> #   value <dbl>

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
code: # Define the date range and parameters start_datetime <- "2025-03-16 00:00" end_datetime <- "2025-03-16 01:00" # using a short interval for testing parameters <- c("PM10") frequency <- "hourly"  # Bulk download air quality data for all stations bulk_data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime = start_datetime,   end_datetime = end_datetime,   parameters = parameters,   frequency = frequency )  # Inspect the combined data glimpse(bulk_data)

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: faster bulk downloads, can use parallel processing. especially useful downloading data many stations large date ranges: can also use parallel processing downloading data single station:
code: # Install parallel processing packages if not already installed # install.packages(c("future", "furrr", "progressr"))  library(future) library(progressr)  # Set up parallel processing with 4 workers plan(multisession, workers = 4)  # Bulk download with parallel processing start_datetime <- "2025-03-16 00:00" end_datetime <- "2025-03-16 01:00" parameters <- c("PM10", "NO2") frequency <- "hourly"  # Option 1: Let the function manage the parallel plan bulk_data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime = start_datetime,   end_datetime = end_datetime,   parameters = parameters,   frequency = frequency,   parallel = TRUE,   workers = 4 # Number of parallel workers )  # Option 2: Set up your own future plan plan(multisession, workers = 4) bulk_data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime = start_datetime,   end_datetime = end_datetime,   parameters = parameters,   frequency = frequency,   parallel = TRUE # Uses your existing plan ) plan(sequential) # Reset to sequential processing  # With progress tracking (requires progressr package) handlers(global = TRUE) # Enable progress handlers handlers("progress") # Use progress bar  with_progress({   bulk_data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(     start_datetime = start_datetime,     end_datetime = end_datetime,     parameters = parameters,     frequency = frequency,     parallel = TRUE,     workers = 4,     show_progress = TRUE   ) })  glimpse(bulk_data) station_id <- "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080" parameters <- c("PM10", "CO", "NO2")  # Download all available data in parallel (parallelizes across time chunks) plan(multisession, workers = 4) all_data <- download_all_data_for_station(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = parameters,   frequency = "hourly",   chunk_size = "3 months", # Smaller chunks = more parallelization   parallel = TRUE,   workers = 4 ) plan(sequential)  glimpse(all_data)

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
code: station_id <- "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080" parameters <- params$name frequency <- "hourly"  # Download all available data for the specified station over the broad default range all_data <- download_all_data_for_station(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = parameters,   frequency = frequency )  glimpse(all_data)

what: Bulk Download 3 - Save All Station Data to Parquet Files
title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: large bulk downloads, can process station sequentially use parallel processing furrr:
code: library(tidyverse) library(arrow) library(future) library(furrr) library(airqualitytr)  # Define the parameters to download. params <- list_parameters() parameters <- params$name # or simply: c("PM10", "CO", "NO2")  # Retrieve station metadata from your package stations_meta <- list_stations()  # Join city names (already included in list_stations() output) cities_meta <- list_cities() stations_meta <- stations_meta |>   left_join(cities_meta, by = "city_id")  # Define frequency for downloading data. frequency <- "hourly" # or "daily"  # Create an output folder to store Parquet files if (!dir.exists("bulk_station_data")) {   dir.create("bulk_station_data") }  # Option 1: Sequential processing (original method) pwalk(   list(     station_id = stations_meta$station_id,     station_name = stations_meta$station_name,     city_name = stations_meta$city_name   ),   function(station_id, station_name, city_name) {     message("Downloading data for station: ", station_name, " (", station_id, ")")      # Call download_all_data_for_station() with only the essential inputs.     # This function automatically uses a broad date range (e.g. 1900-01-01 to 2099-12-31)     # to fetch all available data for that station.     station_data <- download_all_data_for_station(       station_id = station_id,       parameters = parameters,       frequency = frequency     )      # Optionally, if station_data might be huge, you can periodically flush memory or     # simply write the result directly.     file_name <- file.path("bulk_station_data", paste0("data_", station_id, ".parquet"))     arrow::write_parquet(station_data, sink = file_name, compression = "snappy")      message("Saved data to: ", file_name)   } )  # Option 2: Parallel processing with furrr (much faster!) plan(multisession, workers = 4)  future_pwalk(   list(     station_id = stations_meta$station_id,     station_name = stations_meta$station_name,     city_name = stations_meta$city_name   ),   function(station_id, station_name, city_name) {     # Download all available data with internal parallel processing for chunks     station_data <- download_all_data_for_station(       station_id = station_id,       parameters = parameters,       frequency = frequency,       parallel = TRUE, # Also parallelize time chunks       show_progress = FALSE # Disable messages in parallel     )      # Save to Parquet file     file_name <- file.path("bulk_station_data", paste0("data_", station_id, ".parquet"))     arrow::write_parquet(station_data, sink = file_name, compression = "snappy")      return(file_name)   },   .options = furrr_options(seed = TRUE) )  plan(sequential) # Reset to sequential processing

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: Station ID valid UUID format. Solution:
code: # Get valid station IDs from list_stations() stations <- list_stations() valid_station_id <- stations$station_id[1]  # Use this ID in your downloads data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = valid_station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-16 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-17 00:00" )

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: Date range reversed invalid. Solution:
code: # Correct format: "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM" start_datetime <- "2025-03-01 00:00" # Earlier date end_datetime <- "2025-03-31 23:59" # Later date  # Check your dates before downloading lubridate::ymd_hm(start_datetime) < lubridate::ymd_hm(end_datetime)

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: Query returns empty tibble. Possible causes: Station data specified date range Parameters measured station Network connectivity issues API temporarily unavailable Solution:
code: # Check if station exists and is active stations <- list_stations() station_info <- stations |> filter(station_id == your_station_id)  # Try a recent date range (last 7 days) data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = your_station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = format(Sys.time() - 7 * 24 * 60 * 60, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M"),   end_datetime = format(Sys.time(), "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M"),   frequency = "hourly" )  # Check multiple stations to verify API connectivity

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: Downloads taking long. Solutions:
code: # 1. Use parallel processing bulk_data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime = "2025-03-16 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-16 12:00",   parameters = c("PM10"),   parallel = TRUE,   workers = 4 )  # 2. Reduce date range # Instead of years, download months at a time  # 3. Use daily instead of hourly frequency data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = station_id,   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2024-01-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2024-12-31 23:59",   frequency = "daily" # Much smaller dataset )  # 4. Download fewer parameters at once

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: Trying use parallel processing without required packages. Solution:
code: install.packages(c("future", "furrr", "progressr")) library(future) library(furrr)

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: API requests timing . Solutions: Check internet connection Try later (API might maintenance) Reduce number parallel workers Use smaller date ranges fewer parameters
code: # Reduce parallel workers if getting timeouts data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime = "2025-03-16 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-16 12:00",   parameters = c("PM10"),   parallel = TRUE,   workers = 2 # Reduced from 8 )

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: memory using parallel processing. Solutions:
code: # 1. Reduce number of workers workers <- 2 # Instead of 8  # 2. Process in smaller batches # 3. Write results to disk immediately (use Parquet/Arrow) # 4. Use daily frequency instead of hourly

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Problem: progress indication downloads. Solution:
code: # For sequential downloads, ensure cli is installed install.packages("cli")  # For parallel downloads, use progressr install.packages("progressr") library(progressr)  handlers(global = TRUE) handlers("progress")  with_progress({   data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(     start_datetime = "2025-03-16 00:00",     end_datetime = "2025-03-16 12:00",     parameters = c("PM10"),     parallel = TRUE,     workers = 4,     show_progress = TRUE   ) })

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: ’re still experiencing issues: Check function documentation: Review vignettes detailed examples: Report bugs: https://github.com/emraher/airqualitytr/issues Include R version: R.version.string Include package version: packageVersion("airqualitytr") Provide minimal reproducible example Include error messages
code: ?download_air_quality_data ?bulk_download_air_quality_data ?list_stations vignette("getting-started", package = "airqualitytr")

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: package accesses air quality monitoring data Turkish Ministry Environment, Urbanization Climate Change (Çevre, Şehircilik ve İklim Değişikliği Bakanlığı). Official Data Portal: https://sim.csb.gov.tr/

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Important: using data research publications, please: Data licensing terms Citation requirements Usage restrictions permissions Redistribution rights Cite data source (Turkish Ministry Environment) Cite R package used data access Follow specific citation requirements Ministry

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: data: package:
code: Turkish Ministry of Environment, Urbanization and Climate Change. (Year). Air Quality Monitoring Data. Retrieved from https://sim.csb.gov.tr/ citation("airqualitytr")

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Please note: Data provided -Ministry’s monitoring network package validate quality-control data Users responsible data quality checks Station metadata availability may change time Historical data availability varies station stations may gaps missing measurements Always perform data quality assessment analysis.

title: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools
text: Please note airqualitytr project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools — airqualitytr-package
title: airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools — airqualitytr-package
text: Provides functions download explore air quality monitoring data Turkish Ministry Environment, Urbanization Climate Change. Enables researchers access hourly daily measurements PM10, PM2.5, SO2, CO, NO2, NOX, , O3 across monitoring stations throughout Turkey. airqualitytr package provides functions download explore air quality monitoring data Turkish Ministry Environment, Urbanization Climate Change. enables researchers access hourly daily measurements PM10, PM2.5, SO2, CO, NO2, NOX, , O3 across 300+ monitoring stations throughout Turkey.

title: airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools — airqualitytr-package
text: download_air_quality_data(): Download air quality data specific stations bulk_download_air_quality_data(): Download data multiple stations list_stations(): List available monitoring stations list_cities(): List cities monitoring stations list_parameters(): List available pollutant parameters quality_report(): Generate data quality assessment reports

title: airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools — airqualitytr-package
text: Learn using airqualitytr: vignette("getting-started", package = "airqualitytr") - Introduction basic usage vignette("parallel-processing", package = "airqualitytr") - Speed downloads parallel processing vignette("data-quality", package = "airqualitytr") - Assess data quality completeness vignette("long-term-data", package = "airqualitytr") - Download manage long-term datasets

title: airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools — airqualitytr-package
text: GitHub: https://github.com/emraher/airqualitytr Report bugs: https://github.com/emraher/airqualitytr/issues

title: airqualitytr: Turkish Air Quality Data Access Tools — airqualitytr-package
text: Maintainer: Emrah Er eer@eremrah.com (ORCID)

title: Assess Data Completeness — assess_completeness
text: Calculates completeness metrics air quality data, including percentage missing values, gap identification, temporal coverage.

title: Assess Data Completeness — assess_completeness
code: assess_completeness(data, by_parameter = TRUE, by_station = FALSE)

title: Assess Data Completeness — assess_completeness
text: data tibble containing air quality data columns: time, parameter, value by_parameter Logical. TRUE, calculates metrics separately parameter. Default TRUE. by_station Logical. TRUE station_id column exists, calculates metrics separately station. Default FALSE.

title: Assess Data Completeness — assess_completeness
text: tibble containing completeness metrics: parameter Parameter name (by_parameter = TRUE) station_id Station ID (by_station = TRUE) total_records Total number records missing_records Number missing (NA) values valid_records Number valid (non-NA) values completeness_pct Percentage valid records start_date First timestamp data end_date Last timestamp data expected_records Expected number records based frequency coverage_pct Actual vs expected records percentage

title: Assess Data Completeness — assess_completeness
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10", "NO2", "O3"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Get completeness summary completeness <- assess_completeness(data) print(completeness)  # By station (if multiple stations) completeness_by_station <- assess_completeness(data, by_station = TRUE) } # }

what: Bulk Download Air Quality Data for All Stations — bulk_download_air_quality_data
title: Bulk Download Air Quality Data for All Stations — bulk_download_air_quality_data
text: Downloads time series air quality data (e.g., hourly measurements) available stations specified date range given set measurement parameters. function retrieves station metadata via list_stations() available cities via list_cities(), station downloads measurement data using download_air_quality_data().

title: Bulk Download Air Quality Data for All Stations — bulk_download_air_quality_data
code: bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime,   end_datetime,   parameters = c("PM10", "CO", "NO2"),   frequency = "hourly",   show_progress = TRUE,   parallel = FALSE,   workers = NULL )

title: Bulk Download Air Quality Data for All Stations — bulk_download_air_quality_data
text: start_datetime Start date-time "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM" format. end_datetime End date-time "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM" format. parameters character vector pollutant parameters (e.g., c("PM10", "CO", "NO2")). Default c("PM10", "CO", "NO2"). frequency Either "hourly" "daily". Default "hourly". show_progress Logical. TRUE cli package available, displays progress bar. Default TRUE. parallel Logical. TRUE, downloads performed parallel using future furrr packages. must set future plan using option (e.g., future::plan(future::multisession)). Default FALSE. workers Integer. Number parallel workers use parallel = TRUE. NULL (default), uses number workers specified active future plan.

title: Bulk Download Air Quality Data for All Stations — bulk_download_air_quality_data
text: tibble containing combined time series data stations. tibble includes: time POSIXct timestamp measurement. station_id Station identifier. city_name City name station. station_name Station name. parameter Measurement parameter (e.g., "PM10"). value corresponding measurement value. ... Additional metadata columns snake_case (city_id, area_type, etc.).

title: Bulk Download Air Quality Data for All Stations — bulk_download_air_quality_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # Download one hour of data for all stations (small example) bulk_data <- bulk_download_air_quality_data(   start_datetime = "2024-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2024-03-01 01:00",   parameters = c("PM10"),   frequency = "hourly" ) }

what: Check for Invalid Values in Air Quality Data — check_invalid_values
title: Check for Invalid Values in Air Quality Data — check_invalid_values
text: Identifies invalid, impossible, suspicious values air quality measurements. includes negative values, extreme outliers, measurements exceed physically plausible limits.

title: Check for Invalid Values in Air Quality Data — check_invalid_values
code: check_invalid_values(data, parameter_limits = NULL, outlier_threshold = 5)

title: Check for Invalid Values in Air Quality Data — check_invalid_values
text: data tibble containing air quality data columns: time, parameter, value parameter_limits named list maximum plausible values parameter. NULL (default), uses standard limits based measurement ranges. outlier_threshold Number standard deviations beyond value considered outlier. Default 5.

title: Check for Invalid Values in Air Quality Data — check_invalid_values
text: tibble structure input data, plus additional columns: is_negative Logical indicating value negative exceeds_limit Logical indicating value exceeds plausible maximum is_outlier Logical indicating value statistical outlier is_valid Logical indicating value passes checks (TRUE = valid) quality_flag Character describing issue ()

title: Check for Invalid Values in Air Quality Data — check_invalid_values
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10", "NO2"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-07 23:59" )  # Check data quality checked_data <- check_invalid_values(data)  # See flagged values flagged <- checked_data |> dplyr::filter(!is_valid) } # }

what: Download Air Quality Data with Additional Objects — download_air_quality_data
title: Download Air Quality Data with Additional Objects — download_air_quality_data
text: Downloads time series air quality data specified station simulating form POST request Turkish Ministry's air quality data service. addition retrieving raw time series ("Data" object), function attempts extract objects present JSON response ("Summaries", "Monitors", "StationIds", "Parameters"). Station city names automatically retrieved metadata.

title: Download Air Quality Data with Additional Objects — download_air_quality_data
code: download_air_quality_data(   station_id,   parameters,   start_datetime,   end_datetime,   frequency = c("hourly", "daily"),   return_all = FALSE )

title: Download Air Quality Data with Additional Objects — download_air_quality_data
text: station_id character string station's unique identifier. parameters character vector pollutant parameters (e.g., c("PM10", "CO", "NO2")). start_datetime Start date-time "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM" format. end_datetime End date-time "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM" format. frequency Either "hourly" "daily". Default "hourly". return_all Logical. TRUE (default), named list elements data, summaries, monitors, stations, options returned. FALSE, tidied time series data returned.

title: Download Air Quality Data with Additional Objects — download_air_quality_data
text: return_all = TRUE, named list following elements: data tibble time series measurements (columns include time, station_id, city_name, station_name, parameter, value). column names snake_case format. summaries tibble summary data (available; otherwise empty tibble). Column names snake_case format. monitors tibble monitors metadata (available; otherwise empty tibble). Column names snake_case format. stations tibble station metadata (available; otherwise empty tibble). Column names snake_case format. options tibble available parameter/option settings (available; otherwise empty). Column names snake_case format. return_all = FALSE, data tibble returned snake_case column names.

title: Download Air Quality Data with Additional Objects — download_air_quality_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # Download one week of hourly PM10 data data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2024-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2024-03-07 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" ) head(data)  # Download multiple parameters multi_data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10", "NO2", "O3"),   start_datetime = "2024-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2024-03-07 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" ) }

what: Download All Available Data for a Given Station — download_all_data_for_station
title: Download All Available Data for a Given Station — download_all_data_for_station
text: Downloads available air quality measurements specified station iterating manageable date ranges. function automatically retrieves station metadata list_stations() function consolidates chunked downloads single tibble.

title: Download All Available Data for a Given Station — download_all_data_for_station
code: download_all_data_for_station(   station_id,   parameters,   frequency = c("hourly", "daily"),   show_progress = TRUE,   chunk_size = "1 year",   parallel = FALSE,   workers = NULL )

title: Download All Available Data for a Given Station — download_all_data_for_station
text: station_id character string representing station's unique identifier. parameters character vector pollutant parameters (e.g., c("PM10", "CO", "NO2")). frequency Either "hourly" "daily". Default "hourly". show_progress Logical. TRUE, displays informative messages download. Default TRUE. chunk_size character string specifying size download window passed seq.POSIXt() (e.g., "1 month", "1 year"). Defaults "1 year". parallel Logical. TRUE, downloads performed parallel using future furrr packages. must set future plan using option (e.g., future::plan(future::multisession)). Default FALSE. workers Integer. Number parallel workers use parallel = TRUE. NULL (default), uses number workers specified active future plan.

title: Download All Available Data for a Given Station — download_all_data_for_station
text: tibble containing available time series air quality data given station. tibble includes columns time, station_id, station_name, parameter, value, metadata columns retrieved station information. column names snake_case format.

title: Download All Available Data for a Given Station — download_all_data_for_station
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # Download all available data for a station all_data <- download_all_data_for_station(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10", "NO2"),   frequency = "hourly",   chunk_size = "3 months" ) }

code: format_api_error(error_type, details = NULL, http_status = NULL)

title: Enhanced Error Message Formatter — format_api_error
text: Formatted error message suggestions

code: get_api_status()

what: Identify Time Gaps in Air Quality Data — identify_gaps
title: Identify Time Gaps in Air Quality Data — identify_gaps
text: Finds gaps time series data measurements missing extended periods.

title: Identify Time Gaps in Air Quality Data — identify_gaps
code: identify_gaps(data, min_gap_hours = 3, by_parameter = TRUE)

title: Identify Time Gaps in Air Quality Data — identify_gaps
text: data tibble containing air quality data columns: time, parameter, value min_gap_hours Minimum gap duration hours report. Default 3 hours. by_parameter Logical. TRUE, identifies gaps separately parameter. Default TRUE.

title: Identify Time Gaps in Air Quality Data — identify_gaps
text: tibble containing identified gaps: parameter Parameter name (by_parameter = TRUE) gap_start Start time gap gap_end End time gap gap_hours Duration gap hours missing_records Estimated number missing records

title: Identify Time Gaps in Air Quality Data — identify_gaps
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Find gaps of 6+ hours gaps <- identify_gaps(data, min_gap_hours = 6) print(gaps) } # }

title: Generate Data Quality Report — quality_report
text: Produces comprehensive data quality report including validity checks, completeness assessment, gap identification.

title: Generate Data Quality Report — quality_report
code: quality_report(data, outlier_threshold = 5, min_gap_hours = 3)

title: Generate Data Quality Report — quality_report
text: data tibble containing air quality data columns: time, parameter, value outlier_threshold Number standard deviations outlier detection. Default 5. min_gap_hours Minimum gap duration hours report. Default 3.

title: Generate Data Quality Report — quality_report
text: list containing: summary Overall data quality summary completeness Completeness metrics parameter invalid_values Summary invalid value counts type gaps Identified time gaps flagged_data Data quality flags (invalid records)

title: Generate Data Quality Report — quality_report
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- download_air_quality_data(   station_id = "468478b7-ace5-4bd3-b89a-a9c1c2e53080",   parameters = c("PM10", "NO2", "O3"),   start_datetime = "2025-03-01 00:00",   end_datetime = "2025-03-31 23:59",   frequency = "hourly" )  # Generate quality report report <- quality_report(data)  # View summary print(report$summary)  # View completeness by parameter print(report$completeness)  # View flagged values print(report$flagged_data) } # }

title: Test API Connection — test_api_connection
text: Tests connection Turkish Ministry Environment API verifies required endpoints accessible. Useful troubleshooting connection issues attempting large downloads.

title: Test API Connection — test_api_connection
code: test_api_connection(timeout = 10, verbose = TRUE)

title: Test API Connection — test_api_connection
text: timeout Timeout seconds test. Default 10. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints detailed diagnostic information. Default TRUE.

title: Test API Connection — test_api_connection
text: list containing: overall_status Character: "success", "partial", "failure" tests Tibble results endpoint test recommendations Character vector troubleshooting recommendations

title: Test API Connection — test_api_connection
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Test API connection test_result <- test_api_connection()  # Quick check if (test_result$overall_status == "success") {   message("API is accessible") }  # Detailed diagnostics print(test_result$tests) } # }

title: airqualitytr 0.1.0
text: Initial CRAN release Access Turkish air quality data Ministry Environment API Core functions downloading hourly daily measurements Support PM10, PM2.5, SO2, CO, NO2, NOX, , O3 parameters 300+ monitoring stations across 81 provinces Data quality assessment tools API diagnostics connection testing Comprehensive test coverage (149 tests) Getting started vignette
